title: Update lru crate dependency
body: The lru crate recently fixed a 'use after free bug' https://github.com/jeromefroe/lru-rs/issues/120.

title: Provide a safe way to initialize an OpenGl renderer via glutin.
body:
`OpenGl::new` is quite low-level and will segfault if used incorrectly. This PR introduces the `OpenGl::new_glutin` method which will safely produce an OpenGl renderer from a windowed context.

This PR also marks `OpenGl::new` as unsafe which completely breaks backwards compatibility. Maybe we should mark `OpenGl::new` as deprecated instead?

title: Upgrade to latest ttf-parser
body:
This fixes a rendering bug, at the expense of including two versions of
ttf-parser. But that will be resolved with the next rustybuzz release.

Fixes #56

title: Demo: Path intersection automatically accounts for transforms.
body: Paths are transformed with the current context so there's no need to convert the mouse position to the pre-transform coordinates before testing for intersection. This fixes #62

title: Add five commonly used badges to the README file.
body: See them in action here: https://github.com/Lemmih/femtovg/tree/feature-badges

title: Set Minimum Supported Rust Version (MSRV) to 1.49
Render the usvg::Tree directly rather than going through XML.
body:
The conversion from SVG paths to femto paths is now typed and shouldn't silently break in the future.

Also, this fixes a weird rendering bug (look at the black areas on the nose):

Correctly parse fill and stroke colors in svg example.
body:
This is just a temporary fix. A better solution would use the `Tree` from usvg.

Before:
![svg bad](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1443107/137885686-51458f62-04c6-4451-ab07-8632a4758858.png)

title: Canvas::contains_point doesn't require a mutable Canvas.
body: Closes #52

title: Fix rendering into FBOs with OpenGL ES 2.0
body:
The stencil buffer attachment code on FBOs does not work with a pure GL
ES 2.0 context. The workaround of commit
141b1c079174b04de85e4153a6795bbe876ad9b0 for WebGL is specific to WebGL,
making the attachment work as stencil & depth attachment. However a
combination of both is not supported by pure GL ES 2.0 it seems.

However it appears that the easiest solution is to simply drop the depth
buffer. That appears to work well with desktop GL, a GL ES 2.0 context
(with mesa at least) and WebGL 1 (in Safari). Since femtovg doesn't use
depth testing, that seems like a reasonable compromise.

title: shared fonts
body: This optimizes the font handling code a bit, adds support for face indices and allows sharing font data with the application, thus making it possible to mmap from disk.

title: Add basic support for emojis (color fonts)
body: This patch set includes some refactorings as well as the basic support for color fonts. When rendering emojis, color fonts are typically used. These are true type fonts with new tables that encode emojis as PNG images in various resolutions. ttf-parser is equipped with parsing these tables. So this patch set uses that API to extract the PNG images and renders them into the glyph texture atlas. The glyph size handling isn't quite perfect yet, the glyphs are preferably scaled. It would be nice to change this in the future to use round to the next matching size and increase the overall text layout if the emojis supplied by the font are bigger than the text. Screenshot that shows the result applied to [cargo-ui](https://github.com/sixtyfpsui/cargo-ui):

title: Fix clearing of stencil buffer
body: When filling anti-aliased paths we draw the quad of the bounding box first with the stencil test to achieve the desired anti-aliasing, and afterwards we draw the quad a second time with zero as stencil op (and mask according, etc.) to clear it. This clearing is likely faster than clearing the entire stencil buffer, but if the boundaries are not entirely correct, non-zero values might be left around the edges of the shape in the stencil buffer. When another shape is drawn over a shape that "leaks" into the stencil buffer and that shape has an overall bigger bounding box, the fill of that shape will not only be visible inside its actual shape but also in the places where non-zero values were left over. This patch attempts to correct that by adjusting the bounding box of the path for the purpose of the quad fill by the fringe for anti-aliasing that's not otherwise taken into account. We ran into this in SixtyFPS with a Path element that's drawn like this https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tronical/c42375e9d2c5ada8730527508415d14a/raw/65d0ab8037fd49dd5ae0ede66828023828fae8d1/test.60 [preview](https://sixtyfps.io/editor/?load_url=https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tronical/c42375e9d2c5ada8730527508415d14a/raw/65d0ab8037fd49dd5ae0ede66828023828fae8d1/test.60) screenshot:

title: Expose `TextContext` as "headless" API to measure text and share fonts across canvas instances
body: The API is basically the same as what's already expose in Canvas, with the difference that `TextContext` is using interior mutability and explicit sharing behind the scenes.

title: Add support for applying a gaussian blur filter to images
body:
This adds the

```rust
   pub fn filter_image(&mut self, target_image: ImageId, filter: ImageFilter, source_image: ImageId)
```

function to the renderer, where the ImageFilter is an enum that starts
with a gaussian blur and the standard deviation parameter.

The GL renderer renders this in two passes, a horizontal and a vertical
blur.

Apart from adding filter code path, this patch makes one other change to
the rendering interface: The drawing commands are now moved from the
canvas to the renderer. This is needed because then the second pass in
the blur filter can just change the Command's image parameter, as it
consumes it. Otherwise Command would have to implement Clone, which
would likely be expensive due to the Vec fields within.

title: Fix leaking FBOs with the OpenGL renderer
body:
When rendering into an Image, we store the associated FBO (and depth
stencil RBO) in a hash in the GL renderer, indexed by the image id.
When deleting an image on the canvas, we should also delete the FBO/RBO,
instead of leaking it until the renderer is destroyed.

With this change it's even more important to not delete images that are
used as rendering targets until after flush().

title: Fix polygon area calculation
body:
The previous algorithm was incorrect because it didn't consider the triangle of the last two points and the first point, or of the last point and the first two points. It's been replaced with [one that works without calculating triangle area at all](https://stackoverflow.com/a/1165943).

This fixes some shapes being "randomly" thickened by the AA algorithm:
Before | After
--- | ---
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25993062/115995295-bbdf6280-a5a8-11eb-9491-d85c0a712401.png) | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25993062/115995306-c568ca80-a5a8-11eb-974f-ffaa97b4cf14.png)

Holes in glyphs are still incorrectly thickened, but that's because they're clockwise shapes using the even-odd fill rule, so there's no way to tell that they're holes, and they get offset inwards. That seems to be a much harder problem to fix.

title: Add GitHub Action to run `rustfmt`
changed rustfmt.toml + ran cargo fmt
Added with_-constructors to Paint to simplify setting of parameters
body: Suggestion: Added constuctors of the form `with_` to `Paint`, which simplifies creation of specific paints.

title: Improve stroke_text
body:
Building on #30, using `stroke_text` now also places glyphs in integer positions, making edges much sharper. Any kind of 1px-wide outline is of course going to be somewhat blurry without aggressive hinting (the antialiasing quality is more obvious as well), but this should be an improvement.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7241014/108559823-839b7980-7304-11eb-9220-e52eb2c12ff7.png)

title: Improve text rendering
body:
This PR implements three improvements / fixes to text rendering.

(open the images up to 100% scale to see the difference properly)

Before:
![text example before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7241014/107705553-94763a80-6cc7-11eb-87e1-4cb12b7f53ae.png)

After:
![text example after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7241014/107705448-685ab980-6cc7-11eb-9cfd-4f38508e7144.png)

Side-by-side:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7241014/107706229-a60c1200-6cc8-11eb-9b48-8af4dcbc19e5.png)

### Vertical pixel alignment

When copying from the atlas, glyphs were placed with subpixel offsets in the y-direction and therefore bilinear interpolation was always used. This caused smearing in the vertical direction.

Text is now rendered into the atlas with its baseline aligned to an integer coordinate and glyphs are only copied to integer y-coordinates. I also made `FontMetrics::height` rounded in order to make line spacing consistent.

Follow-up: Should we offer a non-quantized mode for text separately? This would allow smoother scaling animations or finer spacing when needed. I think that mode should always render directly or use a fixed number of oversampled atlas scales. Or do the same subpixel quantization as with x?

### Horizontal subpixel quantization

The quantization applied to glyph x-coordinates only affected the cache ID, but not the actual rendering itself. This should make results more consistent (at most 1/20 px error instead of 1/10).

### Anti-aliasing rook pattern

The anti-alias filter pattern seems to have had a typo, since it looked like this when plotted:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7241014/107707440-88d84300-6cca-11eb-9c0e-f5a5625cfbe1.png)
This is now corrected, subtly improving quality.

title: Fix Canvas::intersect_scissor
body:
When a scissor rect is set initially, state.scissor.extent stores
half of the width and height, and state.scissir.transform holds
the translation matrix to reach the center of the scissor rectangle
(x + w * 0.5, y + w * 0.5).

When intersect_scissor tries to restore the original scissor rect in the
current transform space, the code started out just taking an identity
matrix and applying the inverse of the current transform. The "restored"
scissor rect that would be intersected with the new rect would have the
correct width and height (derived from state.scissor.extent), but it
would not have the correct location, because state.scissor.transform was
not used at all.

This appears to be an oversight in the port from NanoVG, which correctly
starts out with `pxform` at `state.scissor.transform` instead of the
identity matrix.

title: Fix successive calls to `break_text` with different max_width
body:
The results are cached, but the max_width is not part of the key

I didn't see tests for the text shaping, so i did not add one.

title: Fix cargo test
body:
Commit 40a3f187d9110553c86e8c67132ab4234b6c4906 regressed on this, we
need png file support for running the (doc) tests.

title: Add font atlas debug functions, --features "debug_inspector"
body:
cargo run --example text --features "debug_inspector" --release
Debug builds additionally fill unused areas of the font textures
with red to highlight the difference with the glyph boxes.

![Captura de pantalla_2021-01-12_19-25-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2456465/104356277-095d2580-550c-11eb-86d5-236c547ff1b9.png)

title: Add example for Paint::image() making the image fit the path.
Add support for loading HTML image elements as images into the canvas
body: WebGL/glow have built-in support for this.

title: Add glyph margin outside the sampled area, keep padding inside. Fix #22
Make it possible to run the demo in the browser
body:
* canvas glue code in demo.rs takes care of fetching the canvas element.
* From the image crate we don't need the jpeg-rayon variant but the
  regular one, as rayon uses threads, which don't work out of the box
  in Rust's wasm32-unknown-unknown target.
* Assets like fonts and images are embedded into the binary
* The usvg crate has text disabled, because that would pull a bunch
  of dependencies that can't be cross-compiled.
* Use the instant crate to get a wasm working version of the
  performance counter.

title: Add some more code documentation for rustdoc.
Fix WASM build
body:
Use the glow Framebuffer type alias for set_screen_target, which aliases
to Gluint for native GL and a different type for web_sys.

This also includes a small very basic CI setup. Sample build: https://github.com/tronical/femtovg/actions/runs/454885480

title: hide alpha mask functions from public API, and update README.
body:
The alpha mask can only really be used via draw_triangles which also isn't exported (and is only used when drawing text from an atlas). This commit changes the public API by removing Paint::set_alpha_mask and Paint::alpha_mask.

The README removes the note that only two stops are supported in gradients, because we now have multi-stop gradients.

title: feature: add multi-stop gradients
body: This change implements multi-stop gradients, and works for basic cases. It adds a gradient store, which is a cache of gradient textures maintained by the renderer. It might be that we want the Canvas to maintain the gradient cache.

title: opengl: support rendering to an externally-created framebuffer object.
feat(text): Cached 10 subpixel x locations per glyph
Fix for #10 - wrong text rendering on small window sizes
body: canvas.width() and canvas.height() were returning wrong values when rendering to the texture (ref #10)

title: Bump glow version
body: This allows removing the Cargo patch

title: Initial WASM port
body: This implements what's needed for issue #1

title: Port to glow as GL abstraction
body:
This request includes two changes, a port to glow (please review carefully!) and a small change on top to enable a wasm build and make it possible to instantiate the GL renderer accordingly.

If desired I can also split these commits into separate pull requests.

title: Switch from Harfbuzz to Rustybuzz
body:
The latest release of Rustybuzz is now a pure Rust port, without any
external C/C++ dependency. Using it here paves the way for a wasm build,
for example.

title: Support PowerPC (ppc64le) and ARM (armv71).
body:
Tested on IBM Power9 (Raptor Computing Blackbird motherboard)
and Raspberry Pi 400.

We need to update usvg from 0.11 to 0.12 to get a newer release
of rustybuzz that has the same fix on their side since 0.2.0:
https://github.com/RazrFalcon/rustybuzz/commit/32fac2e65624e54bc4b58b0dce2100d8eccaa5dd

title: Fix #2: use high precision in the fragment shader so that linear gradients render correctly on NVidia hardware.
body: The linear gradient code uses extents with small deltas around 1e5, and this causes lumpy interpolation in the sdRoundRect function used to calculate gradients. Box gradients and radial gradients don't use smaller extents and don't have the same issue.
